block.p: International A3-14 AID MAY FLOW TO RUSSIA The International Monetary Fund may relax conditions for freeing aid to Russia. At the same time, officials of the fund pressed President Yeltsin to continue reforms and devote more financial attention to the poor. A1 NEW SECURITY SERVICE FOR RUSSIA President Yeltsin dissolved the K.G.B.'s successor and created a third generation to handle internal security, but left as its head a career K.G.B. agent. A14

International A3-14 AID MAY FLOW TO RUSSIA The International Monetary Fund may relax conditions for freeing aid to Russia. At the same time, officials of the fund pressed President Yeltsin to continue reforms and devote more financial attention to the poor. A1 NEW SECURITY SERVICE FOR RUSSIA President Yeltsin dissolved the K.G.B.'s successor and created a third generation to handle internal security, but left as its head a career K.G.B. agent. A14

THE ROAD TO A NEW SHANGHAI Capitalism is making a comeback in Shanghai, and one of the biggest investors is the Government, which is building the roads and bridges that will allow China's largest city, for years excluded from development plans, to catch up. A1 CHINA PROPOSES EUGENICS LAW A proposal by a Chinese official would use abortion and sterilization to prevent "abnormal" births. A8 HAITIAN LEADER UNMOVED Haiti's ousted President refused to agree to an international conference aimed at restoring him to power and has warned that he may revese his stance on American policy toward Haitian asylum-seekers. A5 SINN FEIN RESPONSE REJECTED The leader of Sinn Fein, the I.R.A.'s political wing responded to overtures for peace in Northern Ireland, but his efforts were rebuffed. A10 A moment of silence for Lockerbie victims. A9 Israelis and Palestinians began talks in Paris. A9 South African negotiators adjourned without a breakthrough. A6 Santiago del Estero Journal: Where poverty boiled over. A4 National A16-21 FIRST LADY MAKES A DEFENSE Hillary Clinton went on the offensive against new accusations about her marriage and scrutiny of the suicide of a longtime friend and aide, saying the White House was being subjected to "outrageous attack." A1 SEEKING AIDE'S FILES Federal law-enforcement officials said they would seek to examine files, removed from the office of the deputy White House counsel shortly after he killed himself, on the Clintons' land dealings. A20 SEX SUITS PROMPT PLEA Faced with dozens of suits stemming from molesting by priests, the Archdiocese of Santa Fe, N.M., is asking parishioners for contributions so it can avoid filing for bankruptcy protection. A1 AN END TO FAST PIZZAS Domino's Pizza ended its marketing promise to deliver pizza within 30 minutes after a jury awarded $78 million to a woman struck by a Domino's driver in 1989. The change could have a profound impact on Domino's business, which depends largely on delivery. A1 POP STAR OUSTS LAWYER Michael Jackson has dismissed his longtime lawyer, aides said, and planned to make a statement to deny accusations that he had molested a boy. A16 AMTRAK TRAIN DERAILS
An Amtrak train from New York derailed in Indiana after it struck a truck. The truck driver was killed and more than a dozen passengers on the train were injured. A18 CAFFEINE AND PREGNANCY
Adding to the debate over caffeine's safety, a study suggested that women who drink coffee increase their risk of miscarriage. A18 SETTLEMENT IN AIDS SUIT

Settling charges that it had discriminated unfairly against members with AIDS, a union welfare fund agreed to pay $100,000 to the estate of a Minnesotan. A19 The number of homeless families is growing, a survey found. A18 As the military shrinks, R.O.T.C. becomes more competitive. A18 Education Page B7 San Diego's Mexican-American center becomes, on Jan. 1, Nafta school.
In School: A measure of success for a military-style camp for dropouts.
Inside a school that follows an alternative path rewarded by Annenberg.

Metro Digest B1 DEVELOPERS' TAX BREAK The New York City Council, ending its legislative session, voted yesterday to extend tax breaks to developers who build large apartment towers in Manhattan. A1 SUPERINTENDENTS OUSTED Two Bronx school superintendents hired to help improve schools and fight graft are being ousted by their local school boards. A1 Business Digest D1 Arts/Entertainment C15-22 France and Spain limit foreign entertainment. C15 The Times names new culture editor. C21 Theater: "Anarchia." C15 Film: "Philadelphia." C15 "Faraway, So Close." C15 Music: A marked diminuendo in classical radio. C15 Books: Nancy Mitford's letters. C21 Television: "On the Town" in concert. C22 Looking back on 1968. C22 The Living Section C1-12 To sip, perchance to steam. C1 At work with Eli Zabar: And in the 90's, they will eat leftovers. C1 Health Page C13 Impotence problems grow with age, a large study finds.

Sports B9-15 Sports B9-15 Baseball: Yanks' Brien Taylor injures shoulder. B9 Mets still seek shortstop. B12 Basketball: Nets defeat Knicks. B9 Boxing: Notebook B11 Column: Anderson on the Giants B9 Football: Giants win in coaching duel too. B9 Eric Thomas gives Jets winning attitude. B12 Tennis: Wrist surgery for Agassi. B13 Obituaries B8 Joseph H. Ball, a former Republican Senator and U.N. Advocate.

Editorials/Op-Ed A22-23 Editorials Wanted: a cabinet of taxpayers. A safety net for Russian reform. The longest night. Thank you, Mr. Dinkins. Letters Bob Herbert: Football's fearful reality. Charles William Maynes: Real politik for the 90's. John Mariani: A Bronx tale of feasting. Neediest Cases B6 Chronicle B6 Bridge C21 Crossword C21
